column3: Remembering there were no willow sticks for the fire, she quickly girdled her blanket tight about her waist, and with a short handled ax slipped through her belt, she hurried away toward the wooded ravine.

column3: Near the entrance way she stooped low, at once shifting the bundle to the right and with both hands lifting the noose from over her head. Having thus dropped the wood to the ground, she disappeared into her teepee.

column2: He was nowhere to be found.

column2: After many days and nights the search was given up.

column2: It was sad, indeed, to hear the mother wailing aloud for her little son.

column2: It was growing late in the autumn.

column2: The birds were flying high toward the south.

column2: The teepees around the lakes were gone, save one lonely dwelling.
column3: The teepees around the lakes were gone, save one lonely dwelling.

column2: Till the winter snow covered the ground and ice covered the lakes, the wailing woman's voice was heard from that solitary wigwam.
column3: Till the winter snow covered the ground and ice covered the lakes, the wailing woman's voice was heard from that solitary wigwam.

column2: From some far distance was also the sound of the father's voice singing a sad song.
column3: From some far distance was also the sound of the father's voice singing a sad song.

column2: Thus ten summers and as many winters have come and gone since the strange disappearance of the little child.
column3: Thus ten summers and as many winters have come and gone since the strange disappearance of the little child.

column2: Every autumn with the hunters came the unhappy parents of the lost baby to search again for him.
column3: Every autumn with the hunters came the unhappy parents of the lost baby to search again for him.

column2: Toward the latter part of the tenth season when, one by one, the teepees were folded and the families went away from the lake region, the mother walked again along the lake shore weeping.

column3: One evening, across the lake from where the crying woman stood, a pair of bright black eyes peered at her through the tall reeds and wild rice.

column2: A little wild boy stopped his play among the tall grasses.
column3: A little wild boy stopped his play among the tall grasses.

column3: His long, loose hair hanging down his brown back and shoulders was carelessly tossed from his round face.

column3: Crouching low to the marshy ground, he listened to the wailing voice.

column3: As the voice grew hoarse and only sobs shook the slender figure of the woman, the eyes of the wild boy grew dim and wet.
